passages.text: Economics - Asia ex-Japan
...which marks a notable shift towards an expansionary fiscal policy.

- The government announced the 2026 budget, with its spending projected to rise by \(8.1\%\) y-o-y, in comparison with the initial 2025 budget (before the extra budgets). However, after including two rounds of extra budgets this year, effective spending growth is slower at \(3.5\%\) y-o-y in 2026. As a result, the managed fiscal deficit is expected to narrow to \(4.0\%\) of GDP in 2026 from \(4.2\%\) (government estimates) in 2025.

- The government will increase spending on R&D and industry transition over the next four years to restructure the economy, which may help reboot the domestic economy. Spending on health/social welfare and national defense is also likely to increase notably to meet growing structural demand.

- We expect a positive impact on growth from higher government spending on R&D and industry. As this is already penciled into our forecasts, we maintain our 2026 GDP growth projection of \(1.9\%\) y-o-y.

- We believe the 2026 budget marks a notable shift towards expansionary fiscal policy, as the managed fiscal deficit is likely to stay higher than the fiscal rule of \(3\%\) of GDP in coming years and that the government debt/GDP ratio will continue to increase.

- Over the medium-term, this could affect the policy mix, as an increasing government debt burden could put pressure on the BOK to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance to support an expansionary fiscal policy.

The government announced the 2026 budget, with expenditure growth projected to increase by \(8.1\%\) y-o-y in 2026 (compared with the initial 2025 budget before the two extra budgets; Figure 1). However, comparing the 2026 budget with the 2025 budget (including the two extra budgets), effective growth slows to \(3.5\%\) far below its five- year average of \(5.4\%\) . The government expects its spending growth to average \(4 - 5\%\) per annum over the next four years.

The government's spending plan shows that the long- term fiscal goal is focused on rebooting the economy with significant spending growth in R&D and industry restructuring/transition (Figure 2). At the same time, the government will continue to increase spending on health / social welfare, and national defense to meet growing structural demand.

The managed fiscal deficit (the fiscal deficit after subtracting the social/public fund surplus from the consolidated fiscal deficit) is expected to narrow to \(4.0\%\) of GDP in 2026 from \(4.2\%\) in 2025, which is still higher than the fiscal rule of \(3\%\) of GDP. The government expects the managed fiscal deficit to remain in a range of \(4.1 - 4.3\%\) of GDP over the next four years, larger than the fiscal rule of \(3\%\) , a notable shift towards an expansionary fiscal policy. Accordingly, the government's debt/GDP ratio is projected to rise to \(51.6\%\) in 2026, and further to \(58\%\) by 2029.
The government also announced its KTB issuance plan of KRW232tm in 2026, largely unchanged from the amount of issuance in 2025, which is consistent with market expectations.
We view the 2026 budget and the government's renewed long- term debt projection as the beginning of an expansionary fiscal policy. Indeed, the government's long- term budget
See Appendix A- 1 for analyst certification, important disclosures and the status of non- US analysts.

projection shows that fiscal spending growth will average \(5.5\%\) per annum over the next four years, outpacing fiscal revenue growth of \(4.3\%\) for the same period, thereby sustaining the managed fiscal deficit at above \(4\%\) of GDP, above the fiscal rule of \(3\%\) .

In terms of the growth impact, we view higher spending on R&D and industry transition (AI and energy sectors, for example) will have a positive impact on growth in 2026 and beyond, which could mitigate the potential downside risk from external headwinds such as higher tariff rates. However, as we have already incorporated the likely increase in government spending on investment into our 2026 GDP forecast (i.e., R&D spending), we maintain our 2026 GDP growth forecast of \(1.9\%\) .

While the government expects its debt to remain under control, we believe debt management will be key to sustaining an expansionary fiscal policy. On the revenue side,it is difficult to expand the tax base, which means there are limited resources to support higher spending growth, though the government is stepping up its efforts for spending cuts to secure more revenue resources. This means there will likely be more enhanced cooperation between the fiscal and monetary authorities to support debt sustainability.

...which may lead to a new policy mix - expansionary fiscal and dovish monetary policyOn monetary policy, we do not see any impact on the BOK's policy decisions in the short-term. However, from a medium-term perspective, an increasing government debt burden could put pressure on the BOK to adopt a more dovish stance to support an expansionary fiscal policy in 2026 and beyond.
Fig. 1: Long-term fiscal projections

Managed fiscal balance = Consolidated fiscal balance excluding the social security funds (i.e., national pension funds).
The government targets to manage the managed fiscal deficit at 3%.
Source: MOFE, Nomura Global Economics
